etymology.description: 歹(歹) (dǎi, "carcass") + 人(人) (rén, "person") = person with remains -> death
etymology.interpretation: The character 死(sǐ, "to die") combines 歹(歹) (dǎi, "carcass") indicating death with 人(人) (rén, "person") to symbolize a deceased person, highlighting its association with human mortality.

examples.chinese: 他的决心大到不怕死(他的決心大到不怕死)。
examples.pinyin: Tā de juéxīn dà dào bù pà sǐ.
examples.english: His determination is so strong that he is not afraid to die.

examples.chinese: 战场上(戰場上)，他见到许多勇士倒下死去(他見到許多勇士倒下死去)。
examples.pinyin: Zhànchǎng shàng, tā jiàndào xǔduō yǒngshì dǎoxià sǐqù.
examples.english: On the battlefield, he saw many brave warriors fall and die.

examples.chinese: 传说中(傳說中)，英雄死后获得永生(英雄死後獲得永生)。
examples.pinyin: Chuánshuō zhōng, yīngxióng sǐhòu huòdé yǒngshēng.
examples.english: According to legend, heroes gain eternal life after death.
